title: United Airlines suffers nationwide ground stop
text:
United Airlines suffers nationwide ground stop Jul 8, 2015, 8:36am CDT Updated Jul 8, 2015, 9:06am CDT Share Travelers wait in line at the United/Continental ticket counter at O'Hare International… more Good luck flying United Airlines today, because the airline is weathering a nationwide ground stop. In tweets, the airline describes the problem causing the stop as an "issue with the passenger service system," and the Federal Aviation Administration's advisory on the ground stop indicates technical issues are at play . Already, delayed passengers are tweeting photographs of long lines and reports are emerging that fliers ought to expect delays throughout the day , even as the United (NYSE: UAL) brings its systems back up to speed. USA Today explained that by 8:30 a.m. Central time, some United regional flights had begun operating again , but both United and United Express flights are expected to battle a ripple effect for hours. UPDATE 1: Lambert Airport in St. Louis tweeted that United ticket counters opened at about 8:45 a.m. At Bradley International Airport, in Connecticut, video showed some passengers checking in manually . UPDATE 2: Early month, United suffered significant delays due to system issues that echoed today's delays. Wired posted a timeline saying that , in that instance, United flights began to be delayed at about 8 a.m. Central, and that about 40 minutes later computer systems started coming back up. That report also passed along passengers' tweets saying that they received various information from flight crews about the cause of the delays, from speculation about a computer hack to issues with flight plans filed incorrectly. UPDATE 3: As of about 9 a.m., the FAA had lifted United's ground stop .
